title: Kitchen Equipment Safety
legalBasis: Royal Decree 1215/1997 on work equipment safety; Law 31/1995 on Occupational Risk Prevention; Royal Decree 486/1997 on workplace conditions; Royal Decree 1644/2008 on machinery; EU Machinery Directive 2006/42/EC
summary:
Commercial kitchens contain numerous specialized pieces of equipment that, while essential for food preparation, present significant safety hazards if improperly used or maintained. Slicers, mixers, food processors, grills, fryers, ovens, and other powered equipment involve mechanical hazards (rotating blades, moving parts that can catch clothing or body parts), thermal hazards (hot surfaces, heated liquids or oils), electrical hazards (high-voltage equipment in wet environments), and specific risks associated with each equipment type. Kitchen equipment injuries range from minor cuts and burns to catastrophic incidents including amputations, severe lacerations, electrocution, and crushing injuries.

Spanish occupational safety law (Royal Decree 1215/1997) establishes comprehensive requirements for work equipment. Employers must provide equipment that is safe and appropriate for its intended use, maintain equipment in safe condition through regular inspection and maintenance, ensure safety guards and protective devices are in place and functioning, train workers in safe operation before allowing unsupervised use, and provide operating and safety instructions in accessible formats. Workers have corresponding duties to use equipment correctly as trained, not disable safety features, report malfunctions or damage, and refuse to use equipment they know to be unsafe.

Most kitchen equipment accidents result from predictable scenarios: inexperienced workers using equipment without adequate training, bypassing or defeating safety guards to speed operations, attempting to clear jams or make adjustments while equipment is still powered, inadequate maintenance allowing equipment to develop dangerous conditions, and inappropriate use of equipment for tasks it was not designed for. Understanding equipment-specific hazards, following manufacturer safety procedures, and maintaining disciplined safety practices dramatically reduces these risks.

This guide covers general safety principles applicable to all kitchen equipment and specific guidance for common high-risk equipment types. However, this guide cannot replace equipment-specific training and manufacturer instructions. Every piece of equipment has unique characteristics and hazards requiring specific knowledge. Workers must receive hands-on training for each equipment type they will operate and should consult manufacturer manuals when questions arise.
keyPoints: Never use any kitchen equipment without first receiving proper training and authorization
Read and understand manufacturer operating instructions and safety warnings before first use
Verify that all safety guards and protective devices are in place and functioning before operating equipment
Never disable, bypass, or remove safety guards — they protect you from serious injury or death
Turn off and unplug equipment before cleaning, adjusting, or clearing jams — lockout/tagout procedures prevent accidental activation
Keep hands, utensils, and loose clothing away from moving parts and hot surfaces
Report any equipment malfunction, damage, or unsafe condition immediately and take equipment out of service
Use appropriate personal protective equipment (cut-resistant gloves, heat protection) for high-risk tasks
Maintain clear workspace around equipment — clutter increases accident risk
Employers must provide safe equipment, maintain it properly, and ensure all operators are trained before unsupervised use

sections.heading: 1. Legal Requirements for Work Equipment
sections.content:
Royal Decree 1215/1997 implements EU Directive 89/655/EEC on work equipment, establishing detailed requirements for equipment safety. Article 3 requires that all work equipment be appropriate for the work to be performed and adapted to protect worker health and safety. Equipment must comply with applicable product safety regulations (for new equipment, the Machinery Directive 2006/42/EC as implemented by Royal Decree 1644/2008) or, for older equipment that predates those regulations, be retrofitted or upgraded to provide equivalent protection.

Employers must conduct risk assessments identifying hazards associated with each equipment type and implementing appropriate protective measures. Annex I of Royal Decree 1215/1997 specifies minimum safety requirements for work equipment including protection against mechanical hazards (guards on moving parts, emergency stops, interlocks preventing access during operation), electrical safety (proper grounding, insulation, protection against wet conditions), protection against thermal hazards (insulation, guards, warning labels), ergonomic design (controls accessible and understandable, appropriate working heights), and provision of safety information (operating instructions, warning labels in Spanish or languages workers understand). Equipment failing to meet these requirements must be upgraded or removed from service.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Employer Obligations
subsections.content:
Employers must ensure all kitchen equipment meets safety standards before putting it into service. For new equipment, verify CE marking indicating compliance with Machinery Directive and request declaration of conformity from manufacturer. For used or older equipment, conduct safety assessment and retrofit with necessary guards and safety devices if deficiencies exist. Maintain equipment in safe condition through preventive maintenance programs (scheduled inspection, lubrication, adjustment, replacement of worn parts), prompt repair of malfunctions, and keeping equipment clean to prevent deterioration and fire hazards.

Employers must provide adequate information and training to all equipment operators covering equipment capabilities and limitations, safe operating procedures, use of safety guards and emergency stops, personal protective equipment requirements, basic troubleshooting and when to call for maintenance, cleaning and daily maintenance procedures, and what to do in emergencies (equipment malfunction, fire, injury). Training must be hands-on and practical, not just reading manuals. Workers should demonstrate competence before being authorized for unsupervised operation. Records of training should be maintained. Equipment operating instructions and safety information must be available at point of use (posted near equipment, in readily accessible manuals, or in digital formats that workers can easily access).

subsections.heading: 1.2 Equipment-Specific Risk Assessment
subsections.content:
The employer's general workplace risk assessment must include specific evaluation of each equipment type. For mechanical equipment (slicers, mixers, food processors, grinders), assess risks from rotating blades, moving parts that can catch or crush, sharp cutting edges, and points where body parts could be drawn into machinery. For thermal equipment (ovens, grills, fryers, griddles, salamanders), assess risks from hot surfaces, heated liquids or fats, steam generation, and fire potential. For electrical equipment, assess risks from electrical shock (particularly in wet kitchen environments), equipment malfunction or damage creating electrical hazards, and improper use of extension cords or temporary wiring.

Risk assessment should also evaluate ergonomic hazards (equipment requiring awkward postures or excessive force to operate, repetitive motions, vibration exposure), environmental factors (noise from equipment, heat generation affecting overall kitchen temperature, ventilation adequacy for fume-producing equipment), and process-specific hazards unique to particular equipment or operations. Based on assessment findings, implement control hierarchy: eliminate hazards if possible (e.g., purchase safer equipment), implement engineering controls (guards, interlocks, safety devices), establish administrative controls (safe work procedures, training, supervision), and provide personal protective equipment as last line of defense.

subsections.heading: 1.3 CE Marking and Product Compliance
subsections.content:
New kitchen equipment sold in the EU must bear CE marking indicating compliance with applicable safety directives, primarily the Machinery Directive. CE marking is the manufacturer's declaration that equipment meets all safety requirements. When purchasing new equipment, verify CE marking is present (usually on a metal plate attached to the equipment), request the declaration of conformity from manufacturer, and obtain operating and maintenance manuals in Spanish or languages workers understand. Absence of CE marking on post-1995 equipment is a serious concern indicating potential non-compliance.

However, CE marking alone does not guarantee safety — equipment must also be used correctly, maintained properly, and operated by trained workers. Moreover, much kitchen equipment predates CE marking requirements. Older equipment can be safe if properly maintained and retrofitted with modern safety features where necessary. Employers cannot simply discard all pre-1995 equipment, but they must ensure it provides protection equivalent to modern standards. This may require adding safety guards, installing emergency stops, improving electrical safety, or in some cases replacing equipment that cannot be adequately upgraded.

sections.heading: 2. General Equipment Safety Principles
sections.content:
Certain safety principles apply across all kitchen equipment types. Understanding and consistently applying these general principles, in addition to equipment-specific procedures, creates a foundation for safe equipment operation. These principles address the most common scenarios leading to equipment injuries: operating without training, defeating safety features, performing maintenance or adjustments while equipment is energized, and inappropriate use of equipment for unintended purposes.

General principles are not substitutes for equipment-specific training and manufacturer instructions. Each equipment type has unique characteristics and hazards requiring specific knowledge. However, workers who internalize general safety principles are more likely to work safely even when encountering unfamiliar equipment or unexpected situations. These principles should be emphasized during initial safety training and reinforced continuously through supervision and workplace culture.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Training and Authorization
subsections.content:
Never operate any kitchen equipment without first receiving proper training and authorization. Training should include reading manufacturer operating and safety instructions, observing experienced operator demonstrating safe use, hands-on supervised practice performing common operations, instruction in troubleshooting common problems, and demonstration of cleaning and basic maintenance procedures. Only after successfully completing training and demonstrating competence should you be authorized for unsupervised operation.

If you encounter equipment you have not been trained to use, do not attempt to figure it out through trial and error — request training from a supervisor or experienced operator. If you have been trained but are uncertain about a specific operation or procedure, ask for clarification rather than guessing. If you have not operated particular equipment for an extended period, request refresher training before resuming use. Overconfidence and assumptions ('this is similar to equipment I have used before, I can figure it out') contribute to many equipment injuries. Always err on the side of caution and request training when needed.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Pre-Operation Safety Checks
subsections.content:
Before operating equipment, perform brief safety checks. Verify all safety guards are in place and properly secured — never operate equipment with guards removed or damaged. Check that emergency stop button or switch is accessible and functional (you should know where it is and be able to reach it quickly). Inspect power cord and plug for damage (fraying, exposed wires, bent prongs); never use equipment with damaged electrical components. Ensure work area around equipment is clear of clutter, spills, and obstacles that could interfere with safe operation. For equipment requiring grounding, verify ground connection is intact.

Check that equipment appears clean and well-maintained — excessive grease buildup, visible damage, unusual wear, or makeshift repairs suggest inadequate maintenance and potential hazards. Verify equipment is stable and properly mounted or positioned — equipment that rocks or can tip over presents obvious danger. If you note any deficiencies during pre-operation checks, do not operate the equipment; report the problem and ensure it is corrected before use. Taking 30 seconds for pre-operation checks can prevent serious injuries.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Lockout/Tagout Procedures
subsections.content:
Lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures prevent accidental energization of equipment during maintenance, cleaning, or clearing jams. The basic principle is simple: before performing any maintenance, adjustment, or clearing operation, completely de-energize the equipment (turn off and unplug, or if hard-wired, open and lock the circuit breaker), apply a lock or tag preventing re-energization (in industrial settings, personal padlocks are used; in kitchens, a tag or sign warning 'DO NOT OPERATE — MAINTENANCE IN PROGRESS' may be used), perform the necessary work, remove tools and ensure area is clear, and only then re-energize equipment.

Many serious kitchen equipment injuries occur when workers attempt to clear jams, adjust blades, or clean equipment while it is still powered. A momentary lapse (accidentally hitting the power switch, equipment with faulty controls starting unexpectedly) can cause catastrophic injury when hands or tools are near blades or moving parts. Lockout/tagout completely eliminates this risk. In kitchens, the most practical LOTO procedure is unplugging equipment before any work on or near moving parts or electrical components. For hard-wired equipment, use the main disconnect switch and apply a tag. Never assume equipment is safe just because the switch is off — energized equipment can start unexpectedly due to faulty controls or accidental switch activation.

sections.heading: 3. Slicers and Cutting Equipment
sections.content:
Mechanical slicers (meat slicers, food processors with slicing blades, mandolins) are among the most hazardous kitchen equipment. The fundamental hazard is obvious: extremely sharp blades rotating at high speed or positioned to cut anything that contacts them, including fingers and hands. Slicer injuries are typically severe: deep lacerations, amputations of fingertips or fingers, and severe nerve and tendon damage. Most slicer injuries occur during specific scenarios: hand slipping or pushed into blade while feeding product, attempting to slice items that are too small and should use a hand guard, cleaning blade while equipment is energized, removing or bypassing blade guard to slice oversized items, and reaching to adjust or clear jammed blade while slicer is running.

Safe slicer operation requires strict adherence to safety procedures, use of provided guards and pusher devices, discipline to stop and de-energize before clearing jams or cleaning, and willingness to refuse unsafe operations even under time pressure. Slicers should never be operated by untrained workers. Given injury severity, employers often restrict slicer operation to experienced staff and prohibit use by new or young workers until they have developed general kitchen safety discipline.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Slicer Safety Features and Proper Use
subsections.content:
Modern slicers have several safety features. Blade guard covers the portion of the blade not actively cutting, preventing contact with most of the blade circumference. Product holder or pusher (a hand guard that holds the product and pushes it through the blade) keeps hands away from the blade during slicing. Thickness adjustment allows precise control of slice thickness without requiring hand proximity to blade. Emergency stop button or switch allows immediate shutdown. Some modern slicers have interlocks preventing operation unless guards are in place. All these features must be used as designed — never remove or bypass them.

Proper slicing technique involves securing product in the holder/pusher firmly, adjusting thickness setting before beginning slicing, starting slicer with hands clear of blade, using smooth steady motion to push product through blade (letting the blade do the work, not forcing), never putting hands near blade for any reason while slicer is running, and stopping slicer completely before removing sliced product. For small items that cannot be safely secured in the holder, do not slice them — either cut by hand with a knife, or do not slice at all. Never attempt to push product through with bare hands or improvised tools. When product becomes too small to safely hold in the pusher, stop slicing and discard or hand-cut the remainder.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Cleaning and Maintenance
subsections.content:
Slicer cleaning presents significant injury risk because it requires proximity to the blade. Always turn off and unplug slicer before cleaning. Remove product tray and other removable components. For blade cleaning, use a brush or cloth, wiping from center of blade outward (away from the sharp edge), never running fingers or hand along the blade edge. Some slicers have blade guards that remain in place during cleaning, providing barrier protection. Use cut-resistant gloves during slicer cleaning for additional protection. Never use aggressive scrubbing motions that could cause hand to slip into blade.

For detailed cleaning or blade removal, consult manufacturer instructions. Blade removal typically requires specific tools and procedures. Only authorized maintenance personnel should remove blades for sharpening or replacement. After cleaning, ensure all components are properly reassembled and guards replaced before plugging in and restarting slicer. Test briefly to ensure normal operation before resuming slicing. Regular professional maintenance should include blade sharpening, lubrication of moving parts, verification of guard integrity, testing of safety interlocks and emergency stops, and inspection of electrical components. Maintain records of professional maintenance.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Hand Guards and Cut-Resistant Gloves
subsections.content:
Use of the provided hand guard or product holder is not optional — it is a critical safety device that must be used for every slicing operation. The hand guard keeps your hand a safe distance from the blade while providing secure grip on the product. If your slicer's hand guard is lost or damaged, do not operate the slicer until a replacement is obtained. Operating a slicer without a hand guard is analogous to driving without seatbelts — the probability of injury on any given use may be low, but the consequences when injury occurs are catastrophic.

Cut-resistant gloves provide an additional layer of protection during slicer operation and especially during cleaning. Wear a cut-resistant glove on your non-dominant hand (the hand that will be nearest the blade). The glove does not eliminate the need for safe technique and proper use of guards, but it can prevent or reduce injury severity if an unexpected slip or contact occurs. Gloves must be clean and food-safe. Some employers prohibit gloves during actual slicing (on theory that gloves reduce dexterity and may create false sense of security) but require them during cleaning. Follow your employer's policy. Whether or not gloves are used during operation, the fundamental rule is simple: keep hands and all body parts clear of the blade whenever it is moving.

sections.heading: 4. Mixers and Food Processors
sections.content:
Commercial mixers (planetary mixers, spiral mixers) and food processors present hazards from rotating attachments (beaters, whisks, dough hooks, processor blades), pinch points where moving attachments meet stationary components, and significant torque that can cause serious injuries if clothing, hair, or body parts become entangled. Mixer injuries include hand or arm caught in rotating attachment causing fractures or tissue damage, long hair or clothing caught in mixer dragging person toward machinery, and crush injuries from planetary mixers with heavy moving bowl lifts. Food processors add hazards from extremely sharp blades that can cause severe cuts even when not rotating.

Safe mixer operation requires understanding that mixers generate substantial force — industrial mixers can exert hundreds of pounds of torque. They will not stop if they catch your hand; they will crush or tear tissue before the motor stalls. Respect this power by maintaining safe distance from operating attachments, never putting hands near moving parts, and always turning off before any interaction with bowl contents or attachments.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Mixer Safety Features and Operation
subsections.content:
Modern commercial mixers have safety features including bowl guard that must be lowered before mixer can operate (prevents access to rotating attachment during operation), emergency stop button for immediate shutdown, interlocks preventing operation unless bowl is properly locked in position, and speed controls allowing starting at low speed then increasing gradually. Older mixers may lack these features; they require extra caution and may need retrofitting with guards. Always verify bowl guard is in position before starting mixer. Never attempt to bypass interlocks to run mixer with guard raised — this defeats critical protection.

Proper mixing procedure involves loading ingredients into bowl before starting mixer, lowering bowl guard completely, starting mixer at lowest speed and gradually increasing as needed, never opening bowl guard or attempting to add ingredients while mixer is running (turn off mixer, wait until attachment stops completely, raise guard, add ingredients, lower guard, restart), and allowing attachment to stop completely before raising guard or removing bowl. If you must scrape bowl sides during mixing, turn off mixer, wait for complete stop, scrape, then restart. The few seconds this takes are trivial compared to the catastrophic injury risk from putting hands or utensils near moving attachments.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Attachment Safety and Entanglement Prevention
subsections.content:
Changing mixer attachments (swapping between beater, whisk, dough hook, etc.) requires caution. Turn off mixer completely and unplug if possible. Allow attachment to stop completely. Follow manufacturer procedure for safe removal (typically twisting and lifting). Handle heavy attachments carefully — dough hooks and industrial beaters can weigh several kilograms. When installing new attachment, ensure it locks securely before operation. A loose attachment can dislodge during operation causing injury or equipment damage.

Prevent entanglement hazards by securing long hair (pull back and cover with hat or hairnet), removing jewelry (watches, bracelets, rings) before operating mixers, ensuring sleeves are tight or rolled up (loose sleeves can catch on rotating parts), and wearing close-fitting clothing (loose aprons or jackets can be caught). These precautions are not mere dress code preferences — they prevent serious injuries. Cases exist of workers suffering degloving injuries (skin torn off) from rings caught in mixers, hair caught in rotating attachments pulling workers into machinery, and clothing entanglement causing fractures. Simple precautions eliminate these risks entirely.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Food Processor Blade Handling
subsections.content:
Food processor blades are razor-sharp and remain dangerous even when not rotating. When assembling food processor, handle blade by the center hub or designated grip area, never by the cutting edges. Place blade in processor bowl carefully, ensuring it locks onto the drive shaft before adding food. When removing blade after processing, turn off and unplug processor, remove bowl from base, carefully lift blade by the hub while supporting from underneath (blades can be slippery when coated with processed food), and place on a clean surface where it will not be accidentally contacted.

Cleaning food processor blades requires extreme caution. Use a brush or cloth to clean blades while holding by the hub. Consider using cut-resistant gloves for this task. Never scrub blades aggressively — the sharp edges can catch the cloth or brush and pull your hand into the blade. Some food processor blades are dishwasher-safe, which is safer than hand washing. If hand washing, place blade in sink with obvious visibility (do not submerge in soapy water where it cannot be seen). Wash carefully and dry immediately. Store blades in a designated safe location (in original box, in a drawer with dividers keeping blades separated, or on a magnetic strip with edges protected), never loose in a drawer with other utensils.

sections.heading: 5. Fryers and High-Temperature Equipment
sections.content:
Deep fryers operate at extremely high temperatures (160-190°C) creating severe burn hazards from oil contact, oil splatter, and steam. Additional hazards include fire risk if oil is overheated or water contacts hot oil, slips and falls from oil spilled on floors, and lifting injuries from handling heavy full fryer vats. Fryer injuries are often severe: deep burns from oil contact requiring skin grafts, oil splash burns to face and eyes potentially causing permanent scarring or vision damage, and catastrophic burns if fryer oil catches fire and spreads.

Safe fryer operation requires understanding oil behavior at high temperatures, strict adherence to temperature limits, careful technique when loading and unloading food, and rigorous attention to fire prevention. Fryers should be operated only by trained workers who understand the hazards and proper procedures. Never leave operating fryers unattended. Know the location of fire suppression equipment (Class F extinguisher, fire blanket) and how to use it before operating fryers.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Fryer Operating Safety
subsections.content:
Before starting fryer, verify oil level is adequate but not overfilled (oil expands when heated and foams when food is added; overfilled fryers will overflow), oil is fresh or filtered (degraded oil has lower flash point and increased fire risk), temperature controls are functioning (test that fryer heats to set temperature and thermostats shut off heating at correct point), and drainage valves are closed and not leaking. When heating oil, never exceed recommended maximum temperature (typically 190°C; higher temperatures risk oil ignition). Use fryer thermometer to verify actual oil temperature matches set temperature — faulty thermostats can allow dangerous overheating.

When adding food to fryer, ensure food is as dry as possible (excess water causes violent spattering and can trigger oil fires), lower food gently using baskets or long-handled utensils (never drop or throw food into hot oil), stand back from fryer as food enters oil to avoid splatter, and never overload baskets (overloading causes oil temperature drop and can cause overflow). When removing cooked food, allow baskets to drain over the fryer before transferring food. Shake baskets gently to promote draining, but avoid vigorous shaking that could splash hot oil. Place hot baskets on designated heat-safe surfaces, never on heat-sensitive materials. Never walk across the kitchen carrying baskets dripping with hot oil — drain thoroughly before moving.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Fire Prevention and Emergency Response
subsections.content:
Fryer fires result from oil reaching its flash point (temperature at which it spontaneously ignites), typically above 300°C for fresh oils. Degraded or contaminated oil has lower flash point. Prevent fires by never exceeding recommended temperature settings, maintaining temperature controls in proper working order, using fresh oil and filtering regularly, keeping fryer area clean and free of grease buildup, and never leaving fryers unattended during operation. Automatic fire suppression systems installed in fryer hoods provide critical protection; ensure they are inspected and maintained per code requirements.

If fryer oil catches fire, do not panic. Never use water (this causes explosive spread of burning oil). Never attempt to move or carry burning oil. Immediately turn off heat source if safe to do so (this removes energy input to the fire). If fire is small and contained in fryer vat, carefully place fryer lid or cover over vat to smother flames, or use fire blanket to cover and smother. If fire is larger or spreading, use Class F fire extinguisher designed for cooking oil fires (aim at base of fire, sweep side to side). If fire is uncontrolled or you are unsure of your ability to extinguish safely, activate fire alarm, evacuate kitchen, and call emergency services (112). Never delay evacuation trying to fight a fire you cannot safely control.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Oil Changing and Cleaning
subsections.content:
Changing fryer oil involves handling large volumes of very hot oil and requires extreme caution. Only perform oil changes when you have been specifically trained and authorized. Never drain hot oil — allow oil to cool to safe handling temperature (below 50°C, ideally close to room temperature). Verify drain valve and receptacle are properly connected before opening drain. Open drain valve slowly and control flow — rapid draining can splash. Use only appropriate oil collection receptacles (metal containers rated for hot oil, never plastic that could melt). Move filled receptacles carefully; hot oil is heavy and unstable. Spilled oil creates severe slip hazards and burn risks.

After draining, clean fryer interior per manufacturer instructions. Ensure fryer is cool and unplugged or de-energized before any cleaning. Use appropriate cleaning chemicals in correct dilutions. Rinse thoroughly to remove all chemical residues. Dry completely before refilling with fresh oil (any water left in fryer will cause violent spattering when new oil is heated). When refilling, verify drain valve is fully closed and sealed before adding oil. Fill to correct level only. Test fire suppression system after oil changes per maintenance schedule. Maintain records of oil changes including date, oil volume, person performing change, and any issues noted.

sections.heading: 6. Electrical Safety in Wet Environments
sections.content:
Kitchens present unique electrical hazards because significant electrical equipment operates in wet conditions. Water and electricity are a deadly combination — water reduces electrical resistance of human body and provides conductive paths for current flow, dramatically increasing electrocution risk. Kitchen electrical hazards include direct contact with energized parts (frayed cords, damaged plugs, exposed wiring), ground faults in equipment (equipment cases becoming electrically energized due to internal faults), wet conditions compromising electrical insulation, and use of electrical equipment with wet hands or while standing in water.

Electrocution can cause cardiac arrest, severe burns, muscle contractions preventing release from electrical source, falls from electrical shock, and death. Even non-fatal electrical shocks can cause serious injuries and permanent effects. Electrical safety in kitchens requires properly designed and installed electrical systems (adequate capacity, proper grounding, ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) protection), well-maintained equipment (no damaged cords, proper grounding), strict procedures (keeping electrical equipment away from water, not operating with wet hands), and immediate response to any electrical problems.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Equipment Grounding and GFCI Protection
subsections.content:
All kitchen electrical equipment must be properly grounded. Three-prong plugs provide grounding connection; the third (round) prong connects equipment case to ground, ensuring that if internal electrical fault energizes the case, current flows to ground rather than through person who touches the case. Never remove or bypass the ground prong on three-prong plugs — this defeats critical protection. Never use adapters ('cheater plugs') that convert three-prong plugs to two-prong without maintaining ground connection. If outlet lacks ground connection, have a qualified electrician install proper grounded outlets.

Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter (GFCI) devices provide additional protection by detecting any current leakage to ground and instantly cutting power. GFCIs are required in wet locations by electrical codes. If your kitchen lacks GFCI protection (particularly in areas near sinks or water sources), request installation by qualified electrician. Test GFCI outlets monthly using the test button; press test button and verify power cuts off, then press reset to restore power. GFCI devices that fail testing must be replaced immediately. For portable equipment, portable GFCI units that plug into outlets can provide protection if permanent GFCI installation is not feasible.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Cord and Equipment Inspection
subsections.content:
Inspect electrical cords and plugs before each use. Look for fraying, cuts, or exposed wires in cord insulation, cracked or damaged plug housings, bent or missing prongs, evidence of overheating (discoloration, melting), and kinks or compression damage. Any damaged cord or plug must be removed from service immediately and repaired by qualified person or replaced. Never attempt temporary repairs with electrical tape — this creates shock and fire hazards. For frequently moved equipment, provide adequate cord length to reach outlets without stretching; taut cords are prone to damage and create tripping hazards.

Avoid using extension cords in commercial kitchens — permanent equipment should have outlets positioned to reach without extensions. If extension cords are absolutely necessary (for temporary equipment or special events), use heavy-duty extension cords rated for the equipment's power requirements (check amp rating), ensure extension cord has ground connection (three-prong), avoid running cords through water or across wet floors, and avoid running cords through doorways or traffic areas where they can be damaged. Never daisy-chain multiple extension cords. Never use indoor extension cords outdoors or in wet locations. Remove extension cords from service when no longer needed.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Safe Practices and Emergency Response
subsections.content:
Maintain electrical safety discipline: Never touch electrical equipment with wet hands (dry hands before operating switches or handling plugs), never operate electrical equipment while standing in water (even small amounts of water on floor create shock hazard), keep electrical equipment away from sinks and water sources where practical, unplug equipment before cleaning (particularly immersible parts or cleaning near electrical components), and report any tingling sensation or mild shock from equipment (indicates ground fault requiring immediate repair). Even mild shocks are warnings of potentially deadly faults.

If someone suffers electrical shock and is still in contact with the electrical source, do not touch them (you will also be shocked). Immediately cut power at the circuit breaker or disconnect switch. If that is not immediately possible and safe to do so, use non-conductive object (dry wooden broom handle, dry rope) to separate victim from electrical source. Once separated from electricity, check for breathing and pulse; begin CPR if needed and summon emergency services (112). Even if victim seems to recover, electrical shock can cause delayed cardiac effects — always seek medical evaluation after any significant shock. Report all electrical shock incidents to employer for investigation; faults causing one shock will likely shock others until repaired.

checklists.title: Daily Equipment Safety Checks
items: Verify all safety guards and protective devices are in place before operating any equipment
Check that emergency stop buttons/switches are accessible and visible
Inspect electrical cords and plugs for damage before use; report and remove damaged items from service
Test GFCI outlets monthly using test button; verify power cuts off and resets properly
Ensure work areas around equipment are clear of clutter, spills, and tripping hazards
Verify equipment appears clean and well-maintained without visible damage or makeshift repairs
Check that equipment is stable and properly mounted or positioned (not rocking or tipping)
For equipment with specific startup procedures (fryers preheating, mixers bowl positioning), follow correct sequence
Never operate any equipment you have not been trained and authorized to use
Report any equipment malfunction, unusual noise, or unsafe condition immediately

checklists.title: Slicer/Cutting Equipment Safety Checklist
items: Verify blade guard is in place and properly secured
Ensure product holder/pusher is available and in good condition
Turn off and unplug slicer before any cleaning, adjustment, or clearing jams
Use hand guard for all slicing operations; never push product through with bare hands
When product becomes too small to safely hold in guard, stop slicing and discard or hand-cut remainder
Wear cut-resistant glove on non-dominant hand, especially during cleaning
Clean blade by wiping from center outward, never running hand along sharp edge
After cleaning, verify all components are reassembled and guards replaced before restarting
Never remove or bypass blade guard to slice oversized items
Test slicer briefly after cleaning to ensure normal operation before resuming production slicing

checklists.title: Fryer Safety Checklist
items: Verify oil level is adequate but not overfilled
Check that oil is fresh or filtered; replace degraded oil
Ensure temperature controls are functioning; verify actual temperature matches set temperature
Never exceed recommended maximum temperature (typically 190°C)
Dry food thoroughly before adding to hot oil to prevent spattering
Lower food gently into fryer using baskets or long-handled utensils; never drop or throw
Stand back from fryer when adding food to avoid splatter
Allow baskets to drain thoroughly over fryer before removing
Know location of fire suppression equipment (Class F extinguisher, fire blanket) and how to use
Never leave operating fryer unattended
If oil catches fire, do not use water; smother with lid/blanket or use Class F extinguisher
Allow oil to cool completely before draining for oil changes; never drain hot oil

bestPractices: Develop equipment-specific competence: seek thorough training for each equipment type before unsupervised use
Make pre-operation safety checks a reflexive habit performed every time before starting equipment
Treat lockout/tagout (turn off and unplug before maintenance/cleaning) as inviolable rule, never shortcut it
Respect safety guards and interlocks as critical protection; never disable or bypass them regardless of time pressure
Report equipment problems immediately and remove malfunctioning equipment from service without hesitation
When in doubt about any procedure, stop and ask for clarification rather than proceeding uncertainly
Maintain awareness of others working near equipment; communicate before starting equipment that could affect them
After any equipment incident or near-miss, analyze what happened and what could prevent recurrence

glossary.Dispositivo de Seguridad: Safety device — guard, interlock, emergency stop, or other protective feature on equipment
glossary.Resguardo: Guard — physical barrier preventing access to dangerous parts of machinery
glossary.Parada de Emergencia: Emergency stop — button or switch for immediate equipment shutdown in emergencies
glossary.Enclavamiento: Interlock — safety device preventing operation unless guards are properly positioned
glossary.Bloqueo y Etiquetado (LOTO): Lockout/tagout — procedure for de-energizing and securing equipment before maintenance
glossary.Toma de Tierra: Ground/earthing — electrical connection to earth protecting against electrocution from equipment faults
glossary.GFCI/Interruptor Diferencial: Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter — electrical safety device that cuts power when current leakage detected
glossary.Marcado CE: CE marking — symbol on equipment indicating compliance with EU safety directives
glossary.Equipo de Trabajo: Work equipment — machinery and tools used in workplace, subject to safety regulations
glossary.Evaluación de Riesgos: Risk assessment — systematic identification and evaluation of equipment hazards
